## Experiment

* Waterfilled horizontal borehole (approx. 9.5 m length)
* Borehole probe with four ring electrodes

![Construction of borehole probe](pics/sonde_en.svg){width="150%"}

* Measurement of resistances $R$ for different depths & different arrays (combinations of current & potential electrodes) $\rightarrow$ $\rho_s=Rk$

## Available electrode arrays

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="65%"}
![](pics/konfig_en.svg){width="130%"}
:::
::: {.column width="30%"}
* little normal (KN):
AM=0.1m
* Schlumberger: AM=BN=0.4m, MN=0.1m
* Upper edge (OK): AM=0.4m,MN=0.1m
* Lower edge (UK): AM=0.4m,MN=0.1m
:::
::::

## Geology & rock types

**Rock types**

* Gneiss (*Freiberger Graugneiss*)
* sulfidic ore zone

**Objective**

* determine location of the ore zone
* estimate resistivity of both formations

## Data analysis
### Matlab
- functions in folder [matlab](https://github.com/TUBAF-EM/MineShaft_Geophysics/tree/main/DCR/matlab): dike2.m, getDike.m

### Python
- functions in folder [python](https://github.com/TUBAF-EM/MineShaft_Geophysics/tree/main/DCR/matlab)
- create environment with *numpy*, *matplotlib*

## Python

::: {.columns}
::: {.column}
```python
from dike import getDike
x = np.arange(0, 6, 0.05)
KN, SL, OK, UK = getDike(
    300, 20, x, thick=2, pos=2)
```

## Report

1. Compute geometric factors for the three arrays
1. Load the data and plot them
1. Compute the theoretical response of a dike
1. Change the parameters (position & thickness of dike, background & dike resistivity) by trial and error
1. Interpret your results
1. Explain why SL data can be retrieved by UK&OK? Check with data
